item.title: Created Issue: E-mail address value may have readable interpretation
item.description:
The RSS 2.0 schema fails to validate e-mail addresses written in the form stated in the examples for the managingEditor and webMaster elements. The author of the specification is of the opinion that users should be to write a humanly readable interpretation of the local part in the email address, like this:

managingEditor geo@herald.com (George Matesky)
webMaster betty@herald.com (Betty Guernsey)

Although the schema should validate this form, it must be pointed out that the RSS 2.0 examples are yet another deviation from standard email address notations stated in RFC 5321 and RFC 5322. For these RSS e-mail addresses to be compatible with SMTP systems they should read:

managingEditor George Matesky <geo@herald.com>
webMaster Betty Guernsey <betty@herald.com>

Unfortunately the spec is further messed up by an obvious typo in the example for the author element:

author oprah\@oxygen.net

Here the backslash isn't even an allowed character in an SMTP address. This last error has been corrected in version 2.0.10 of the specification, which is being maintained by the RSS Advisory Board.

Greetings Philip
item.author: pdonner
item.guid: Created Issue: E-mail address value may have readable interpretation 20081103064432A

item.title: Commented Issue: Channel element can contain one rating element
item.description:
I'm using rss2schema-2.0.2.15 in my application. Created the following test file:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-16" ?>
<rss version="2.0">
<channel>
<title>ZNAK RSS rating test</title>
<link>http://www.znak.fi/rss/channel/rating/</link>
<description>A test feed with a channel rating element</description>
<rating>(PICS-1.1 "http://www.rsac.org/ratingsv01.html" l by "webmaster@example.com" on "2007.01.29T10:09-0800" r (n 0 s 0 v 0 l 0))</rating>
<item>
<title>RSS Test Item</title>
<link>http://www.znak.fi/rss/channel/rating/</link>
<description>RSS channel rating test</description>
</item>
</channel>
</rss>

The msxml parser informs the user:

Element 'rating' is unexpected according to content model of parent element 'channel'.
Expecting: 'title', 'link', 'description', 'language', 'copyright', 'managingEditor', 'webMaster' etc.

Can you do something to make the schema conform to this aspect of the RSS 2.0 spec?

Thanks Philip
Comments: ** Comment from web user: jthelin **

Fixed in release rss2schema-2.0.2.16
item.author: jthelin
item.guid: Commented Issue: Channel element can contain one rating element 20081102043048A

Fixed with this check-in.

item.title: Closed Issue: Move type def for rss element in-line for improved compativility with Java 1.6 tools
item.description:
fgaucho
Sep 15 at 4:24 AM

The only minor change I was forced to do in order to compile the code using Java's wsimport was in the element RSS, since JAXB marshaler and unmarshealer doesn't includes the @XmlRoot annotation in elements that has no children.

So, the change to make codeplex workable with Java 1.6 standard tools is:

before:

<xs:element name="rss" type="Rss"/>
<xs:complexType name="Rss">
...
</xs:complexType>

after:

<xs:element name="rss">
<xs:complexType>
<xs:sequence>
<xs:element name="channel" type="RssChannel" />
<xs:any namespace="##other" processContents="lax" minOccurs="0"
maxOccurs="unbounded" />
</xs:sequence>
<xs:attribute name="version" type="xs:decimal" use="required"
fixed="2.0" />
<xs:anyAttribute namespace="##any" />
</xs:complexType>
</xs:element>

From discussion thread:
http://www.codeplex.com/rss2schema/Thread/View.aspx?ThreadId=35668
item.author: jthelin
item.guid: Closed Issue: Move type def for rss element in-line for improved compativility with Java 1.6 tools 20080923031234A

http://www.codeplex.com/rss2schema/Thread/View.aspx?ThreadId=35668

item.title: Commented Feature: Add Code Samples showing how to create RSS feed from compiled classes
item.description:
fgaucho
Aug 20 at 4:36 AM

Hi there,

I compiled the Rss 2.0 schema, and I got the classes from it (Java code). Everything fine, and my question is about how to populate the TRss element ?

my goal:

<rss version="2.0">
<chanel>
<title>test</title>
</chanel>
</rss>

my last trial:

Rss rssFeed = new Rss();
rssFeed.getOtherAttributes().put(new QName("", "version"), "2.0");

TRssChannel channel = new TRssChannel();
channel.getTitleOrLinkOrDescription().put(new QName("http://www.thearchitect.co.uk/schemas/rss-2_0", "title"), "Cars @ Cejug Classifieds");

a code sample in any language would be cool :)
Comments: ** Comment from web user: jthelin **

Release rss2schema-2.0.2.14 includes C# code samples showing how to construct an example RSS 2.0 feed file using data classed generated by the .NET xsd.exe tool.
item.author: jthelin
item.guid: Commented Feature: Add Code Samples showing how to create RSS feed from compiled classes 20080909062113A

item.title: Commented Issue: Channel element can contain zero or more Item elements
item.description:
Issue reported by Ken Gruven.

When trying to validate some RSS2 here (with xmllint), I discovered that your XSD doesn't pass a RSS2 feed with zero <item>s.

According to the spec: "A channel may contain any number of <item>s." <http://cyber.law.harvard.edu/rss/rss.html>. (And zero is a number!)

I think the line:
<xs:element name="item" type="tRssItem" maxOccurs="unbounded"/>
should read:
<xs:element name="item" type="tRssItem" minOccurs="0" maxOccurs="unbounded"/>
Comments: ** Comment from web user: jthelin **

Related issue: 11186
http://www.codeplex.com/rss2schema/WorkItem/View.aspx?WorkItemId=11186
item.author: jthelin
item.guid: Commented Issue: Channel element can contain zero or more Item elements 20080907055801P

item.title: Closed Issue: Bug-fix for issue 10231 made this schema non-deterministic with respect to extensibitity elements.
item.description:
TODO:
- Unfortunately the bug-fix for issue 10231 made this schema non-deterministic with respect to extensibitity elements.
We can't tell whether an extension element in tRssChannel is within the choice or after the item elements.
Need to reconsider the solution to bug-fix 10231.
Comments: Fixed in release 2.0.0.13
item.author: jthelin
item.guid: Closed Issue: Bug-fix for issue 10231 made this schema non-deterministic with respect to extensibitity elements. 20080907055632P

item.title: Commented Feature: Define a profile of the RSS 2.0 spec with a defined ordering of element, which would allow proper cardinality constraints to be applied
item.description:
Title: xml-schema for rss

Message:

Where do I find your latest xml-schema for rss? The one I found seems to validate the following rss ok. Is that <xs:choice> really ok?

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>

<rss version="2.0" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation=" http://www.thearchitect.co.uk/schemas/rss-2_0.xsd" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance">

<channel>
<title>String</title>
<title>String</title>
<title>String</title>
<item>
<title>String</title>
<title>String</title>
<title>String</title>
</item>
<item>
<title>String</title>
<title>String</title>
<title>String</title>
</item>
<item>
<title>String</title>
<title>String</title>
<title>String</title>
</item>
</channel>
</rss>

//Tommy



This is caused by limitations in the ability of XML Schema language to express the cardinality and flexible element ordering requirements defined in the original RSS 2.0 specification which required a sequence of xsd:choice schema elements to represent faithfully.

I think the only real answer here is to define a profile of the RSS 2.0 spec with a defined ordering of element, which would allow proper cardinality constraints to be applied.
I'll need to work on that one some more.
Comments: ** Comment from web user: jthelin **

This is caused by limitations in the ability of XML Schema language to express the cardinality and flexible element ordering requirements defined in the original RSS 2.0 specification which required a sequence of xsd:choice schema elements to represent faithfully.

I think the only real answer here is to define a profile of the RSS 2.0 spec with a defined ordering of element, which would allow proper cardinality constraints to be applied.
I'll need to work on that one some more.
item.author: jthelin
item.guid: Commented Feature: Define a profile of the RSS 2.0 spec with a defined ordering of element, which would allow proper cardinality constraints to be applied 20080907054706P
